chapter.para: The ECB Backplane interconnects up to eight ECB cards. It provides switched power with a LED power on indicator

The Theory of Operation cannot hope to fully explain the entire board, but at least some helpful notes will be provided. Generally this should aim to exceed a simple list of features, without going into design detail. A good analogy is there is a physical walkthru at the start of the construction section, this section is more of a conceptual or theoretical walkthru.

chapter.para: A #4 wood screw does not quite fit in the ECB or PCB holes, but a 1/8th inch drill after assembly will fit it. The #4 wood screw head will fit in the molded recess provided on top of the ECB connector for nut. Combined with sixteen nylon #4 1/4 inch spacers this makes a fairly attractive mounting option.

The ECB backplane PCB visually appears to be symmetric, but its actually about a sixteenth of an inch longer at the bottom (held with power connector to the left. This may be a manufacturing tolerance issue. Regardless of the reason, its a good idea to lay out your backplane mounting holes with the board facing the correct way rather than assuming if you need to, at final assembly you can flip it.

caution.para: Very few (no?) boards in the project accept any power source other than pure, filtered positive 5 volts

chapter.para: VLM uses a Jameco 175662 for $22.95 as of 2013-01-18 5 amp 5 volt switching power supply to turn 12 volt house power into 5 volts. You also need a female 4 pin molex plug off a burned out PC power supply to connect to the onboard connector. Also two #4 wood screws to mount it, some heat shrink tubing to protect the connections, and some crimp on screw terminals will complete the power supply. On the input of the 12 volt supply VLM uses powerpole connectors, a fuse might be a good idea too.
A backup battery, perhaps two AA batteries in series, can be connected to JP1.

caution.para: Please be careful about polarity when connecting the backup battery to JP1.
